pymerkle.proof module¶

Provides the main class for proof objects and related functionalities

class pymerkle.proof.proof(generation, provider, hash_type, security, encoding, proof_index, proof_path)[source]¶

Bases: object

Base class for the proof object

Basic purpose of this class is to organize the provided proof data in a nicely formatted dictionary, so that they can be handled by the validations module.

Parameters:
  • generation (str) – Should be 'SUCCESS' or 'FAILURE' plus explanation message, according to whether or not a proof path could indeed be generated by the provider Merkle-Tree
  • provider (str) – uuid of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • hash_type (str) – Hash type of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • security (bool) – Security mode of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • encoding (str) – Encoding type of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • proof_index (int) – Position where the validation procedure should start from (provided by the Merkle-Tree)
  • proof_path (list of (+1/-1, str)) – Path of signed hashes (provided by the Merkle-Tree)

Note

Required Merkle-Tree parameters (hash_type, security and encoding) are necessary for proof validation (cf. the validations module)

Variables:
  • header – (dict) Contains the keys uuid, generation, timestamp, creation_moment, provider, hash_type, encoding, security and status (see below)
  • header.uuid – (str) uuid of the proof (time-based)
  • header.generation – (bool) True or False according to whether or not a proof path could indeed be generated by the provider Merkle-Tree
  • header.timestamp – (str) Creation moment of the proof (msecs) from the start of time
  • header.creation_moment – (str) Creation moment in human readable form
  • header.provider – (str) uuid of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • header.hash_type – (str) Hash type of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • header.encoding – (str) Encoding type of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • header.security – (bool) Security mode of the provider Merkle-Tree
  • header.status – (bool) True resp. False if the proof was found to be valid, resp. invalid after the last validation. If no validation has yet been performed, then it is None.
  • body – (dict) Contains the keys proof_index, proof_path
  • body.proof_index – (int) See the homonymous argument of the constructor
  • body.proof_path – (list of (+1/-1, str)) See the homonymous argument of the constructor
JSONstring()[source]¶

Returns a nicely stringified version of the proof’s JSON serialized form

Note

The output of this function is to be passed in the print() function

Return type:str
serialize()[source]¶

Returns a JSON structure with the proof’s current characteristics as key-value pairs

Return type:dict
class pymerkle.proof.proofEncoder(*, skipkeys=False, ensure_ascii=True, check_circular=True, allow_nan=True, sort_keys=False, indent=None, separators=None, default=None)[source]¶

Bases: json.encoder.JSONEncoder

Used implicitely in the JSON serialization of proofs. Extends the built-in JSON encoder for data structures.

default(obj)[source]¶

Overrides the built-in method of JSON encoders according to the needs of this library
